physical_appearance:This is a set of batik shawl and kain panjang. They both have similar motifs. Both feature stylised mythical birds with opened and elaborate wings and feathers
 amidst flowering tendrils. A winged animal enclosed within a medallion and bordered by tendrils creates a repeated pattern. The shawl has tassels attached to either end.
subject_terms_1:shawls Peranakan foliage (motif) birds (motifs) legendary beings
subject_terms_2:Shawls Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people)
subject_terms_3:Batik Peranakan costumes
sgcool_label_text:Mythical birds with elaborate plumage are shown amidst flowering tendrils on this shawl.  Two diamond shaped medallions emphasise a particular type of winged animal that is enclosed within.  It is surrounded by other types of birds set against a cream background with dotted background patterning.  Tassels are attached on both ends of the cloth.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.

metadata.title_text: A set of garment - shawl and kain panjang Shawl and Kain panjang
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a set of batik shawl and kain panjang. They both have similar motifs. Both feature stylised mythical birds with opened and elaborate wings and feathers, amidst flowering tendrils. A winged animal enclosed within a medallion and bordered by tendrils creates a repeated pattern. The shawl has tassels attached to either end.
metadata.subject_terms_1: shawls Peranakan foliage (motif) birds (motifs) legendary beings
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Mythical birds with elaborate plumage are shown amidst flowering tendrils on this shawl.  Two diamond shaped medallions emphasise a particular type of winged animal that is enclosed within.  It is surrounded by other types of birds set against a cream background with dotted background patterning.  Tassels are attached on both ends of the cloth.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.
